title: #69 – Ronesh Sinha, M.D.: Insights into the manifestation of metabolic disease in a patient population predisposed to metabolic syndrome, and what it teaches us more broadly
content: In this episode, Dr. Ronesh Sinha, a physician, author, and educator based in Silicon Valley, shares his many insights into metabolic illness that he has gleaned from his South Asian patient population. In this conversation we focus on hyperinsulinemia, insulin resistance, metabolic dysregulation, inflammation, blood pressure, obesity, etc. and ways to address them with nutrition, sleep, exercise, stress management, and more. We also take a deep dive into insulin resistant phenotypes, evolutionary theory and geographic determinants of insulin resistance which provides insight into the genetic architecture and pathophysiology of metabolic syndrome. Additionally, we discuss the surprisingly interrelated topic of stress, and how we might be inadvertently passing this on to our children, leading to mental and physical sickness down the road.  Subscribe on: APPLE PODCASTS | RSS | GOOGLE | OVERCAST | STITCHER The Peter Attia Drive #69 - Ronesh Sinha, M.D.: Insights into the manifestation of metabolic disease in a patient population predisposed to metabolic syndrome, and what it teaches us more broadly The Peter Attia Drive         The Peter Attia Drive         #69 - Ronesh Sinha, M.D.: Insights into the manifestation of metabolic disease in a patient population predisposed to metabolic syndrome, and what it teaches us more broadly           #69 - Ronesh Sinha, M.D.: Insights into the manifestation of metabolic disease in a patient population predisposed to metabolic syndrome, and what it teaches us more broadly           More Speed: 50% Speed: 75% Speed: Normal Speed: 125% Speed: 150% Speed: 175% Speed: Double Speed: Triple Back 15 seconds Forward 60 seconds More more Speed: 50% Speed: 75% Speed: Normal Speed: 125% Speed: 150% Speed: 175% Speed: Double Speed: Triple Back 15 seconds Forward 60 seconds Currently Playing Download More We discuss: How a stubborn case of insulin resistance connected Peter with Ronesh [7:15]; Download Download Subscribe Subscribe Share Share § Show NotesHow a stubborn case of insulin resistance connected Peter with Ronesh [7:15] How Peter and Ron connected: Peter had a patient from India who had an unusually stubborn case of insulin resistance There was something about it that looked a little different from the usual hyperinsulinemia (there was an “impressive degree” of inflammation) This particular case led Peter to Ron’s book, The South Asian Health Solution Peter and Ron eventually connected (thanks to an introduction by Mark Sisson) Ronesh’s clinical treatment focus of metabolic illnesses in South and East Asian patient populations [8:45] In medical training, diabetes and cardiovascular disease case studies are typically African American, Caucasian, history of smoking, etc. Based in the  Bay Area/ Silicon Valley,  East and South Asian heritage were predominant population with early onset or family history of diabetes Realized there was a gap in resources between how physicians are educated and the populations most afflicted with metabolic diseases (e.g., insulin resistance, diabetes, cardiovascular disease) Decided to create East and South Asian population-specific educational materials and protocols  Around the same time, Ronesh personally developed metabolic syndrome  Prompted him to step outside nutrition guidelines and look more closely at insulin resistance   He was following low fat, low-calorie model diet (eating meat, fish, healthy starch Bengal-style diet of his heritage) Gradually tinkered with personal and patient macronutrient meal composition  Tracked triglycerides (TGs) between making changes Patients had high carbohydrate diet  Relationship between carbohydrate (CHO) and fat revealed that high triglycerides (a.k.a: blood fat) were not reduced by a low fat diet Cut down on dietary CHO and prescribed more liberal dietary fat intake  By contrast, African American patients can present with normal TGs and have diabetes  Prompted Ronesh to look at patient habitus  South and East Asian patients had slender limbs with less lean body mass  Lean body mass allows for the ability to process TGs  The population he treats has a high degree of visceral fat  Significantly higher proportion of visceral to subcutaneous fat High visceral fat is responsible for the degree of inflammation seen in insulin resistance at low body weight   The distinction between visceral fat and subcutaneous fat stores [15:00] Three classifications of fat:  Superficial subcutaneous fat (adipose) tissue (SSCAT) Deeper layer of subcutaneous adipose tissue (DSCAT), right underneath the skin  Visceral fat Figure 1. East and South Asian populations have more adipose tissue stored as VAT rather than as “safety belt” subcutaneous fat, putting them at higher risk for metabolic disease. Image credit: (health.harvard.edu) The city versus suburb analogy for subcutaneous and visceral fat “The way I explain it to people is think of sort of a city versus a suburb. So the subcutaneous fat is really out in the suburbs, the superficial. The deep is a little bit further in, so this could be basically South San Francisco and the visceral is basically around the organs.” The subcutaneous or “suburban” fat structures are organized and have less access to blood supply  Ronesh considers this safeguard against having deeper tissue fat stores  These fat stores are more inert, with little Free Fatty Acids (FFAs) flux in and out of fat cells (responsible for inflammation) Deeper tissue subcutaneous fat and visceral fat are less organized and have access to blood supply and to the liver  High degree of Transmembrane flux And a resulting presence of inflammatory mediators such as Adipokines and inflammatory chemicals Ronesh wrote a blog post about types of adipose tissue, ethnic-specific fat storage, and the health risks that visceral fat stores confer to the Asian population Shortcomings of a body mass index (BMI) calculator for evaluating metabolic disease risk [17:15] Body type of South and East Asian men and women exemplify how physical appearance does not necessarily indicate metabolic health (Body mass index (BMI) calculator would not be an accurate indication for metabolic health) Men are typically thin and skinny but metabolic markers are elevated (“Skinny fat”) Women may have more subcutaneous but metabolic markers like TGs and HDL-C are healthy  Typically in men, unlike for women, the lack of subcutaneous fat insulation means that fat is predominantly stored as visceral fat A study by Mitch Lazar that evaluated a combination resulting in four phenotypes: lean/overweight body weight with healthy/non-healthy metabolic markers, concluded that lean individuals with elevated metabolic markers had the worst outcomes (compared to overweight individuals who were also metabolically ill) The combination of higher proportion of subcutaneous fat stores and larger leg muscles facilitate lipid metabolization  Considering the lipid overflow hypothesis first proposed by Roger Unger– in which fat storage is favored from subcutaneous to deep subcutaneous then lastly, visceral fat stores – larger subcutaneous fat stores insulate the body  Larger leg muscles in heavier individuals help process lipids  South Asians are predisposed to insulin resistance in part due to visceral fat storage Does Ronesh observe an association between patient TGs and their glycemic numbers? Perhaps because patients are still in early stages but elevated TGs does not always present with glycemic impact (high blood glucose) Ronesh refers to these patients as pre-prediabetic Fatty liver, elevated TGs, often with a family history of diabetes, but their  glucose levels are fine (glucose tolerance) *Ronesh wrote a detailed blog post on fatty liver in adults and kids* Important population to educate before becoming prediabetic: they still have preserved beta-cell function (as opposed to Beta-cell failure) and Hyperinsulinemia  When tested, usually present with high fasting insulin levels  “ …I absolutely get the ones that come in with full blown prediabetes or type two diabetes and triglyceride, but I’d say the majority of the population that I see, they’ve already got fatty liver, they’ve got high triglycerides, but their glucose looks fine. And that is a really important population to really educate because I’m telling them now that you don’t have prediabetes, you have pre-prediabetes and this is where we can make the most impact..” The difficulty in developing a unified theory of metabolic disease Peter does not like the way diabetes is defined The problem with Hemoglobin A1C: There is discordance between imputed average blood glucose from hemoglobin A1C and actual measured average glucose   Using calibrated Dexcom (CGM) over the course of 90 days, he identifies patients’ average blood glucose 75% of his patients have average blood glucose that does not match imputed average blood glucose Peter himself is discordant (he hypothesizes due to his beta thalassemia minor) in that his hemoglobin A1C test overstates his average blood glucose compared to Continuous glucose monitor (CGM)  reading Peter does not consider test sensitive enough to evaluate more subtle hemoglobin A1C differences  Ronesh also confirms his clinical observation that the hemoglobin A1C test does not always align with other metrics to evaluate patient metabolic health  Patients who exhibit glucose excursions after eating are not treated as high risk for metabolic syndrome when they should be, despite acceptable average blood glucose Figure 2. For looking at an individual’s glucose values, CGM is a better tool for measuring average sugar levels, time-in-range, and hypoglycemia. Image credit: (diatribe.org) A continuous glucose monitor (CGM) is a valuable tool for metabolic health management Highlights inconsistency between inferred average blood glucose from hemoglobin A1C and measured average blood glucose Provides insight into blood glucose variability  Peter’s patients value wearing a CGM  Insights gleaned  Able to see glucose response of certain foods How glucose intake in conjunction with/within another food can delay glycemic response Role of sleep, proximity to exercising, and time of day on blood glucose levels Gamification and behavior modification  Becomes less about new insights  Altered behavior reinforced by achieving favourable blood glucose numbers Hawthorne Effect  in practice  Working towards a more robust diabetes diagnostic criteria, Peter proposes taking into account fasting and fed glucose levels, insulin levels, inflammatory markers Peter has observed elevated night time glucose levels by CGM in heavier weight patients who are otherwise metabolically healthy: Could cortisol levels be responsible? Cortisol and blood glucose variability [28:30] Ronesh observed, both personally and in his patients, that implementing nighttime rituals such as meditation and switching off devices, decreased fasting (morning) blood sugar  The liver dictates morning blood sugar and Cortisol impacts the liver  For individuals that are insulin resistant, liver is primed to produce high levels of glucose because of a high level of free fatty acids (FFAs) shuttled to liver to fuel gluconeogenesis   Adipose tissue release more FFAs via lipolysis The addition of stress cortisol further increases lipolysis: Cortisol likewise releases FFAs from adipose tissue   Blood glucose improves with decrease in stress: The “emotional metabolic issue”  Ronesh observed an elevated morning glucose in patients when their diets were too low in CHO, especially in the evenings ⇛ For more on the different kinds of lipids, what do they do, and how are they transported: check out a previous episode of The Drive with Tom Dayspring (specifically starting at 57:15) Figure 3. The process of glucose metabolism in the liver. For individuals that have that are insulin resistant, liver is primed to produce high levels of glucose because of a high level of free fatty acids (FFAs) shuttled to liver to fuel gluconeogenesis. Image credit: slideplayer.com The level of hepatic glucose output is tightly regulated 100 milligrams of circulating glucose (a teaspoon measure equivalent) separates a metabolically normal individual from someone with type 2 diabetes  An organism would die in a matter of minutes from Hypoglycemia after clamping the portal vein – thereby preventing the liver from circulating glucose  Why can’t the liver – in an individual with type 2 diabetes – decrease hepatic glucose when blood glucose is elevated in the morning? It is not clear how much blood glucose is regulated by the liver, pancreas, and within muscles  Suspected that cortisol plays an important role  Similarly, what dictates blood glucose variability in a metabolically healthy individual? Cortisol plays an important role in fat flux through a fat cell  Difficult to measure Hormone-sensitive lipase Cannot measure free cortisol in the blood “I think cortisol is a vastly underappreciated regulator of fat flux through the fat cell. Insulin gets a lot of attention because it’s perhaps the most potent both on the side of lipolysis and Re-esterification.” – Peter Attia Insulin’s role in elevated blood glucose: A symptom of metabolic syndrome [33:25] ⇒ For more on central paradox of insulin resistance check out a previous episode of The Drive with Jason Fung (specifically starting at 29:30) Insulin gets a lot of the “credit” in the context of metabolic syndrome  Jason Fung’s model of insulin resistance explains that hyperinsulinemia rather than “resistance” drives metabolic syndrome insulin receptors and/or intracellular mechanisms are not “broken” Insulin-mediated fat deposit into fat cells operates normally, suggesting normal function of insulin  Elevated level of insulin is due to difficulty “pushing” glucose into already full Glycogen stores Ronesh uses the parking space analogy of muscle glycogen stores when educating patients Refer to his lecture at Google at 6:24 where he discusses the parking lot model and at 29:50 where he explains gender disparity in fuel distribution Mechanistic explanations of insulin resistance (there may be more than one) [35:15] “And there may not be one cycle, because I think I was trying to find one process flow that would explain all these cases. There could be multiple. We can see arrows and diagrams going in multiple directions. And I realized at a certain point that I need to understand this process, but I’m probably not going to figure it out exactly for each individual patient.” In some cases, glycogen store capacity is not physical but induced in utero This study in South Asian and Hispanic patient populations with a family history of diabetes develop insulin resistance in utero  Normal glucose tolerance offspring of diabetic parents Elevated FFA is an early insulin signal inhibitor for glycogen storage Fat flux in the liver may precipitate metabolic syndrome in some cases, but in other cases, patients present with negative symptoms without having fatty liver or elevated TGs There are different categories of insulin resistance that will apply to different patients, although the mechanistic explanations are not well understood  Peter focuses on hyperinsulinemia  He educates his patients about the endocrine system, explaining four: Thyroid system, Adrenal system, sex hormone, fuel partitioning  There is often patient confusion around what fuel partitioning means Can simplify fuel partitioning problem by looking at one element of it in hyperinsulinemia   Relies on (oral) glucose tolerance test (OGTT), using Glucola – which has limitations (not reflective of physiologic glucose disposal), but is a standardized comparison model Peter hopes for better point-of-care insulin testing and mentions that developments are being done in this space to further improve the glucola-type test.  CGM provides a measure of glycemic response in a real-world setting (whereas OGTT is taken in the morning, not in response to what a patient would ordinarily consume to spike blood glucose) Theories on origins and evolutionary reasons for insulin resistance [40:00] “…Because I think even in the early days since I developed it, I had this toxic relationship with glucose, triglycerides…” There have been different theories around the origins of insulin resistance…  James Neel first proposed the Thrifty Gene Hypothesis  Insulin resistance is a result of human ancestors living in feast/famine cycles Excess calories in the body would be stored as TGs, which would be utilized during famine periods However evidence does not support that primitive humans experienced periods of famine and an actual “thrifty” gene was never identified  The Barker Hypothesis is not based on an actual gene but a gene phenotype Intrauterine environment (in-utero stress) can trigger insulin resistance and heart disease David Barker looked at birthweight records in the UK, revealing that birthweight was inversely proportional to mortality for heart disease. This relationship has been supported in every continent, with the exception of Africa Dr. C.S. Yajnik work on babies in Prune, India reveals early signs of infant hyperinsulinemia  Babies have pot bellies suggesting visceral fat  Skinfold measures suggest limited amount of subcutaneous fat  Dr. C.S. Yajnik proposed the Soldier to Diplomat Hypothesis  in which insulin resistance is an evolutionary adaptation that allows humans to preserve more glucose for brain function Gerald (Jerry) Reaven who coined the term “metabolic syndrome” agreed that there is likely an evolutionary reason to preserve glucose for brain function  Metabolic shifts (elevated)  glucose and lipids in utero has a trophic (neural developmental) impact  The South Asian population are the most highly insulin resistant country in the world  Dr. Yajnik’s research supports that hyperinsulinemia in utero may have some adaptive function to facilitate brain function and cognition (has  positive trophic impact)   Elevated glucose and elevated insulin can presumably have some impact on increasing IQ and intelligence   It could be that postprandial elevated blood glucose after a fast/carbohydrate restriction is an evolutionary response to refuel the brain  Jake Kushner sent Peter a paper that looked at mechanisms for why refeeding after carbohydrate restriction produces elevated blood glucose However… the analysis did not collect Urinary c-peptide (seemed “underfunded” says Peter) Testable hypotheses: if muscle is resistant to insulin or if there is a delayed pancreatic response Ronesh’s ideas … Proceeding a fast period, the brain takes priority Insulin resistance may occur at the skeletal muscle – which is responsible for 80%-90% of glucose disposal – in order to preserve glucose for brain function He predicts that insulin secretion would be normal In addition to skeletal muscle resistance, there is also likely β-cell dysfunction that contributes to elevated blood glucose  Flooding a system with insulin depresses β-cell function (pancreatic insulin production) Patients in early stage insulin resistance already have decreased β-cell function Pune India fetal studies found that fetal hyperinsulinemia was coupled with underdeveloped β-cell function A “standard” Caucasian path to metabolic disease = normal → hyperinsulinemic → obese → diabetic  Asian populations seem to skip the obesity phenotype on their way to becoming metabolically dysregulated  One reason could be because they predominantly do not present with hyperinsulinemia South Asian population genetically have decreased pancreatic β-cell density Subcutaneous fat obesity may not be a proximate reason for metabolic dysfunction  Lean (low amount of subcutaneous fat) habitus Asian populations still present with metabolic dysfunction A study took metabolically dysregulated people who underwent liposuction but did not metabolically improve  Liposuction removes subcutaneous fat but it is primarily the visceral fat stores that play a role in metabolic disease There has not yet been a study in animal models that surgically remove visceral fat stores to evaluate metabolic impact The inverse relationship between the amount of brown adipose tissue and rates of insulin resistance, and the role of climate in patterns and prevalence of insulin resistance [49:50] Brown adipose tissue research reveals population-specific phenotypes related to climate Figure 4. Brown adipose tissue specializes in dissipating heat as energy. As such newborns have high amounts of “brown fat” responsible for thermogenesis. Image credit (cell.com) Brown adipose tissue is heat-generating (metabolically active), mitochondrially-dense, and can remove glucose from the system An animal model study used brown adipose tissue transplantation to reverse insulin resistance  There is an inverse relationship between the amount of brown adipose tissue and rates of insulin resistance in human populations  Following the “out of Africa Migration”… Populations in northern, colder climates require a more active thermogenic metabolism  Have higher resting metabolism Can generate more heat – their thermogenic resting metabolism can account for 15-18% of caloric burn rate Have more brown adipose tissue  Have a lower incidence of insulin resistance Studies that compare the brown adipose tissue of South Asians and Europeans reveal that South Asians have significantly less brown adipose tissue The Inuit and Eskimos in colder regions have very low insulin resistance Pima Indians have a higher risk of insulin resistance  Metabolic phenotypes within the Indian subcontinent Between the northern and southern regions of India, there are marked differences in rates of insulin resistance, amount of brown adipose tissue, and body morphology  An epidemiologic study of insulin resistance and diabetes in different regions of India reveals vastly different rates of diabetes between northern (Manipur) and southern (Kerala) regions Northern populations near the  Himalayas … have low incidence of insulin resistance  The Manipur region have single-digit insulin resistance and diabetes Body habitus tend to be leaner and taller  Lighter skin tone with not as high observed vitamin D deficiency  Southern Indian populations near the equator… have higher rates of insulin resistance  The Kerala region has an insulin resistance of up to 20% Body habitus tend to be shorter with more visceral fat (pot bellies)  Darker skin tone with vitamin D deficiency  Academic talent from country primarily comes from southern India ⇒ supports theory that in-utero insulin resistance imports cognitive benefit Although there is more insulin resistance  Although there are confounders such as diet and activity level differences between populations, studies done on more rural, physically active southern populations still reveal relatively high rates of insulin resistance  “But in general, if you look at the globe and you look at insulin resistance patterns, climate has a lot to do with it. And it might lead to a phenotype of basically who can manage baseline adipose metabolism better in terms of generating heat.” Vitamin D levels, hyperinsulinemia, and other effects [53:45]  A lot of vitamin D deficiency Ronesh sees in South Asian patient populations is due to their skin pigment He writes about vitamin D deficiency here (1,2)  Population is both vitamin D resistant and individuals do not absorb enough  More (vitamin D) is not necessarily  better… South Asians may not be adapted to have high vitamin D levels  If he does supplement vitamin D for patients in the single digit ng/ml, Ronesh anecdotally has observed that … that supplementing vitamin D improves C-reactive protein (anti inflammatory benefits) Helps with hypertension as patient blood pressures improve Even though vitamin D helps with glucose disposal, he has not observed significant glycemic improvements with supplementation High placebo effect on energy levels with supplementation  Ronesh is hesitant to supplement aggressively due to high rates of coronary calcification that he sees in the treatment population Peter no longer replaces vitamin D in his patients to achieve 40-60 ng/ml  He wants his patients to be above 30 ng/ml without supplementation He personally no longer supplements with vitamin D  Although Peter has not observed that vitamin D supplementation lowers blood pressure, he focuses on decreasing uric acid  The effect of uric acid on blood pressure is significant  Decreasing uric acid content lowers blood pressure (uric acid hypothesized to be an evolutionary adaptation to increase blood pressure) Does not suggest antihypertensive medication until uric acid is below 5mg/dl Correcting uric acid levels does not correct hyperinsulinemia  The evolutionary benefit of being able to turn fructose into fat (and the price we are now paying for it) [58:00] “…This ability to generate uric acid is not unique to all species. It’s something quite unique to those that came from the lineage of having to survive a cold winter without much food.” —Peter Attia Richard Johnson has done research on the uricase mutation during the early Miocene era (∼17 Ma) in a population that migrated to Europe   Fructose is the primary nutrient in fruit, which was a main staple of early primates Fruit became less available during the global cooling that occurred at the time of these mutations Progressive loss of uricase activity allowed ancestors to readily accumulate fat via the metabolism of fructose (through de novo lipogenesis in the liver) from fruits  One byproduct of the conversion of sugar into fat is uric acid However, in today’s society, the intake of fructose, primarily in the form of added sugars, has skyrocketed, while the intake of natural fruits high in vitamin C has fallen One hypothesis that the progressive loss of uricase activity allowed our ancestors to readily accumulate fat via the metabolism of fructose from fruits and survive harsh (and fruitless) winters ⇛ A study discussing the difference between fructose and glucose The VO2 max relationship with insulin resistance and familial metabolic health [59:30]  In a weight, age-matched control trial, a study reported hyperinsulinemic individuals have a lower VO2 max  In early states of insulin resistance the muscle becomes inefficient at oxidative phosphorylation (marked by high levels of resting lactate) In a study of lean individuals with a family history of diabetes:  Without signs of insulin resistance, and normal glucose tolerance   their VO2 max is already decreased offspring with a family history of diabetes had a 5% ATP output in response to VO2 max test compared to the 90% ATP output of individuals without a family history of diabetes ATP output suppression suggests early mitochondrial dysfunction prior to signs of metabolic disease Root cause of mitochondrial dysfunction for healthy offspring individuals with a family history of insulin resistance is not clear Increased amount of FFAs in offspring could affect beta-oxidation  Could be something wrong with oxidative phosphorylation gene expression  One study suggests lower cardiorespiratory fitness (submaximal VO2 max) and reduced capacity to oxidize fat (fatty acid utilisation) represents a defect in substrate delivery to muscle, rather than in mitochondrial capacity to oxidise lipids (no marker for abnormal mitochondrial biogenesis) Figure 5. Beta-oxidation is the catabolic process by which fatty acid molecules are broken down in the mitochondria in eukaryotes to generate acetyl-CoA. One hypothesis for why the South Asian population may have a low VO2 max and an associated high resting lactate phenotype comes from a reduced capacity to oxidize fat (fatty acid utilisation) from which energy is generated. Image credit: (microbenotes.com) The suppressed ATP output of diabetic offspring individuals compared to control (individuals that do not come from a family history of diabetes) suggests that their mitochondria does not catalyze ADP to ATP across the inner membrane in the same way  Suggests mitochondria preferentially undergoes aerobic glycolysis (Warburg Effect) *It is still not clear if mitochondrial dysfunction is causal for diabetes or if it is an early, secondary symptom  that precedes mitochondria gene expression Figure 6. In early states of insulin resistance, the muscle becomes inefficient at oxidative phosphorylation (marked by high levels of resting lactate). During glycolysis – rather than convert to pyruvate, NADPH, and ATP – glucose breaks down to lactate, NADPH and fewer ATP molecules. Image credit:  Medium.com ⇛ For more on on what VO2 max can reveal about mitochondrial function, insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, checkout a previous episode of The Drive with Vamsi Mootha (specifically starting at 2:00:00)   Using a Zone 2 fitness test to evaluate mitochondrial performance [1:01:15] Compared to a Vo2 Max test, a Zone 2 fitness test test more accurately assesses mitochondrial efficiency  VO2 max test can be trained for (and via weight management) Test is not diluted by anaerobic metabolism involved in VO2 max test A VO2 max test …  Maximizes aerobic capacity but also involves anaerobic metabolism  typically uses three minutes stages at increasing power output until failure (measuring real-time VO2) A zone 2 fitness test … Uses lactate as a proxy to clamp lactate in order to assess maximum ATP production samples lactate after long stage time interval (10-15 minute) on fixed power setting on a treadmill or bike Uses lactate as a proxy to clamp lactate in order to assess maximum ATP production samples lactate after long stage time interval (10-15 minute) on fixed power setting on a treadmill or bike Produces a lactate performance curve  lactate threshold is in the 3.8 to 4.2 millimolar range and the performance curve remains below this range (below aerobic threshold)  ⇛ For more on Peter’s zone 2 training prescription check out a previous episode of The Drive (specifically starting at 35:30)  In order to improve mitochondrial performance…  Peter thinks that training 3 hours a week in zone 2 teaches the system to generate more power with a lower lactate  Without buying a lactate device to finger prick, consider a zone 2 proxy to be the highest level of exertion while being able to carry out a conversation    Exercise for long-term functional health [1:06:00] In his insulin resistant Asian patients with lean body morphologies… Ronesh emphasizes balancing physical activity that builds  aerobic endurance without compromising muscle mass Exclusive or predominant weight training facilitates increased glycogen storage capacity but patients became cardiovascularly deconditioned without doing other kinds of exercise He observed that cardiovascular deconditioning had impact on further improvements in insulin resistance and glucose tolerance ⇛ An overview study of why Asian Indians are at such high risk for Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease and Diabetes “Finding that delicate balance of, ‘Yes, we’ve got to build up your aerobic system but we don’t want to compromise your muscle mass’, is sort of critical.” Ronesh observes lean Asian patients more readily lose muscle mass than other ethnic groups when doing volume endurance training As an explanation, studies in athletes reveal AMPK inhibition
